ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I now speak a decent amount of Chinese.

I came into this course with no previous experience in the Chinese language. Now that the semester is over, I know that I have learned how to read Chinese characters, write in both characters and pinyin, learned the correct pronunciation and tones in speaking, and how to understand the grammar and sentence structure in both spoken and written Chinese.
I learned so much about Chinese grammar, tonality, and vocabulary, as well as pronunciation!

I learned many new skills including study habits and techniques that I can bring over to my future classes and future language classes. Some of the skills include my knowledge in Chinese and learned how to write and speak in Chinese. Some insights I got from this course was that I want to continue my classes in Chinese.
We learned a lot of characters, Chinese grammar, and the basics to start speaking Chinese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I don't think the emphasis on character writing should be as prominent. Other than that, this class is extremely effective at teaching a lot of material quickly.

The biggest strength of the course is that it is extremely organized. There is a learning curve at the beginning, but once you understand the weekly calendars and the assignments we do for each unit, you do not feel overwhelmed despite the massive amount of content we are taught in a single semester. The only downside is that because there is so much to cover in so little time, there are moments when you feel rushed. However, the in-class practice and homework supplement the learning so you don't feel unprepared for too long.
I sometime felt like our dictations used characters that we had not been expected to learn, but other than that I loved everything about the course!
I think the strengths was that the concepts taught were very useful; however, some weaknesses included slowing down. I think we were moving along too quickly in the lessons in the book.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Most certainly. It's a tough course, but you'll learn a ton.

Yes. I had the opportunity to take L5 in another language, but choosing to learn Chinese turned out far better than I had expected. As I said, the learning is very organized and there is no lack of support because they understand that Chinese is very different from other languages. Now, I have friends I met in the Chinese program who I continue to text in Chinese because there is a great desire to learn and improve. Chinese is actually very fun.
Yes, absolutely. I feel like I learned more in one semester than I have in many other Yale courses that I have taken.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because I think the concepts and language taught are very useful.

I would completely recommend taking this class if you have the extra overhead to do a lot of work and really want to learn Chinese. You learn so much in such a short amount of time and although theres a lot of work, its spread out consistently everyday through homework and coming to class.
